awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Three-Dimensional Printing of Micro-Capillary Needle via Direct Laser Writing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this SBIR Phase I project leverages recent advances in additive manufacturing to solve key technical hurdles and design deficits of current industry standard microcapillary needles.  Microinjection is a well-established engineering technique and widely used in research and medical applications such as drug discovery and development, fertility treatments, and genetics research.  The proposed technology will use additive (3D) manufacturing techniques for a new microcapillary needle to improve the quality, reproducibility, rigor, and efficacy of this method for a market estimated at $290 M.  This technology will positively impact life sciences research and medical applications.
 
The proposed project will utilize state-of-the-art submicron-scale additive manufacturing technologies to revolutionize microinjection efficacy via substantive versatility in the design and fabrication of the needle-tip. In particular, two-photon direct laser writing (DLW) – wherein a focused laser is precisely positioned within a biocompatible photo material to produce 3D structures comprising cured material – provides an unparalleled level of geometric control with feature resolutions on the order of 100 nm. These capabilities enable new flexibility in re-architecting of the microneedle tip. In addition, due to recent enhancements in printing speed, DLW-based applications can now shift from niche demonstrations in the laboratory to fully functional commercial products that support rapid operation at scale.  The project proposes multiple configurations for each proposed design change with respect to key performance metrics: the anti-clogging efficacy and fabrication repeatability.  This project will: establish and characterize novel manufacturing protocols, simulate expected characteristics, experimentally assess (both in the lab and in vitro using the zebrafish embryo) the quantitative efficacy of these distinct and novel architectures, and qualitatively evaluate the user's experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Microinjection is a technique that allows scientists and physicians to insert small amounts of material into living cells, using a glass microneedle. This method is pivotal to advancements in areas like biology research and disease prevention. It is also an essential tool for fertility therapies such as in-vitro fertilization (IVF), genetic testing before implanting embryos, and certain eye treatments.

In research settings, glass microneedles are typically handmade in the lab, by applying heat and pulling on a glass tube until it is sharp and has a few microns-wide opening at the front of the needle.

Despite its wide use, this traditional method has a few downsides. For example: because each needle is handcrafted, there are inconsistencies between them. This results in extra time spent on calibrating the needles. Furthermore, these needles often get clogged with the materials from the injected cells, which affects their performance over time.

In our project we aimed to address these problems. We utilized a cutting-edge 3D printing technology called Two-Photon Direct Laser Writing (DLW). Firstly, we believed that this 3D printing approach would allow us to create needles with greater precision and consistency, which would make it easier to calibrate them. Secondly, we hypothesized that moving the needle’s opening from the top to the sides would reduce clogging, as material would flow in multiple directions, and it would be harder to block the openings. We believed that these changes would make microinjection process more efficient and reliable.

Our first round of testing confirmed our thoughts. The precision of the DLW technique allowed us to make more accurate and consistent needles compared to the traditional hand-pulled glass needles. Additionally, our new needle design with the side-opening, showed a significantly lower clogging rate compared to traditional needles.

In summary, our new 3D-printed needles have shown great potential. The findings suggest that we should continue to focus on the side-opening design in the next development phase, as we work towards commercializing this innovation.

 


Last Modified: 05/30/2023
Modified by: Kinneret Rand

Image
  • Sequential images of a Zebrafish embryo at 24 hours post fertilization developmental stage, injected with Rhodamine B dye, using the 3D-printed multi-side port needle design.
    Prof. Rachel Brewster lab at University of Maryland Baltimore County (UMBC)
    Copyrighted
    Kinneret Rand
    Zebrafish embryo microinjection
